channel.title: Comments on: Don’t Rely Solely On jQuery’s “keyup” Event

item.title: By: Les Nightingill
item.dc:creator: Les Nightingill
item.description: imho it's best to turn browser auto-fill off for input fields for which you wish to supply autocompletion suggestions. %input{:autocomplete => 'off'} if you're using haml.
item.content:encoded: imho it’s best to turn browser auto-fill off for input fields for which you wish to supply autocompletion suggestions. %input{:autocomplete => ‘off’} if you’re using haml.

item.title: By: Battaile
item.dc:creator: Battaile
item.description: Using input/onInput is probably going to be an inadequate solution as its pretty crap in IE.
item.content:encoded: Using input/onInput is probably going to be an inadequate solution as its pretty crap in IE.

item.title: By: Derick Bailey
item.dc:creator: Derick Bailey
item.description: I didn't even now that existed! I'll have to look into it. Thanks :)
item.content:encoded: I didn’t even now that existed! I’ll have to look into it. Thanks :)

item.title: By: Domenic Denicola
item.dc:creator: Domenic Denicola
item.description:
What you want is the `input` event.
(Also, none of this has anything to do with jQuery...)
item.content:encoded:
What you want is the `input` event.

(Also, none of this has anything to do with jQuery…)

item.title: By: Johnny Oshika
item.dc:creator: Johnny Oshika
item.description:
Great post, Derrick!
Pasting a value by right-clicking and selecting "Paste" in the textbox also doesn't fire a keyup event, so that's another reason not to rely only on the keyup event.
item.content:encoded:
Great post, Derrick!

Pasting a value by right-clicking and selecting “Paste” in the textbox also doesn’t fire a keyup event, so that’s another reason not to rely only on the keyup event.
